verification_notes: The claim is essentially correct in the standard finite-group genuine-equivariant setting. In Hill–Yarnall, Definition 1.1 defines the regular slice filtration by localizing subcategories generated by cells of the form G_+ \wedge_H S^{k\rho_H} (with stage condition k|H|\ge n). Their Theorem 2.5(2) gives the detection criterion: E\in\tau^G_{\ge n} iff for every H\le G, \Phi^H(E) is in the corresponding Postnikov-connective subcategory (equivalently \lceil n/|H|\rceil-connective). So geometric fixed points detect slice-connectivity for the filtration generated by those regular slice cells. Minor wording caveat: Theorem 2.5 detects membership in \tau_{\ge n}, not individual generators cell-by-cell. Primary sources used: https://people.math.rochester.edu/faculty/doug/otherpapers/hill-yarnall.pdf and corroborating terminology in https://people.math.rochester.edu/faculty/doug/otherpapers/ullman-slice.pdf

verification_notes: Core idea is right, but the stated equivalence is missing a Weyl-group factor. For a regular slice cell C=G_+\wedge_H S^{k\rho_H}, the H-geometric fixed points are (equivariantly) \Phi^H(C)\simeq W_G(H)_+\wedge S^k (or, in the normal-subgroup form, G/H_+\wedge S^k). So \Phi^H(C) is generally a wedge of copies of S^k, not a single S^k unless W_G(H) is trivial. This omission does not change the vanishing criterion: maps out of a finite wedge of S^k vanish iff \pi_k(\Phi^H X)=0. The index conversion is correct: k|H|<n is equivalent (for integer k) to k<ceil(n/|H|), i.e. vanishing for i<ceil(n/|H|). Closest direct discussion of induction/geometric-fixed formulas appears on MathOverflow (not Math.SE), while Math.SE gives supporting pieces about fixed-point/Weyl behavior.
